trans-unit.source: Using Azure CLI with Azure Resource Manager (ARM)
trans-unit.target: Using Azure CLI with Azure Resource Manager (ARM)

trans-unit.source: Before you can use the Azure CLI with Resource Manager commands and templates to deploy Azure resources and workloads using resource groups, you will need an account with Azure (of course).
trans-unit.target: Before you can use the Azure CLI with Resource Manager commands and templates to deploy Azure resources and workloads using resource groups, you will need an account with Azure (of course).

trans-unit.source: If you do not have an account, you can get a [free Azure trial here](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).
trans-unit.target: If you do not have an account, you can get a [free Azure trial here](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you don't already have an Azure account but you do have a subscription to MSDN subscription, you can get free Azure credits by activating your [MSDN subscriber benefits here](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/) -- or you can use the free account.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you don't already have an Azure account but you do have a subscription to MSDN subscription, you can get free Azure credits by activating your [MSDN subscriber benefits here](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/) -- or you can use the free account.

trans-unit.source: Either will work for Azure access.
trans-unit.target: Either will work for Azure access.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Verify the Azure CLI version
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Verify the Azure CLI version

trans-unit.source: To use Azure CLI for imperative commands and ARM templates, you need to have at least version 0.8.17.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure CLI for imperative commands and ARM templates, you need to have at least version 0.8.17.

trans-unit.source: To verify your version, type `azure --version`.
trans-unit.target: To verify your version, type `azure --version`.

trans-unit.source: You should see something like:
trans-unit.target: You should see something like:

trans-unit.source: If you need to update your version of Azure CLI, see [Azure CLI](https://github.com/Azure/azure-xplat-cli).
trans-unit.target: If you need to update your version of Azure CLI, see [Azure CLI](https://github.com/Azure/azure-xplat-cli).

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Verify you are using a work or school identity with Azure
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Verify you are using a work or school identity with Azure

trans-unit.source: You can only use the ARM command mode if you are using an [Azure Active Directory tenant](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj573650.aspx#BKMK_WhatIsAnAzureADTenant) or a [Service Principal Name](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn132633.aspx).
trans-unit.target: You can only use the ARM command mode if you are using an [Azure Active Directory tenant](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj573650.aspx#BKMK_WhatIsAnAzureADTenant) or a [Service Principal Name](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn132633.aspx).

trans-unit.source: (These are also called *organizational ids*.)
trans-unit.target: (These are also called *organizational ids*.)

trans-unit.source: To see if you have one, log in by typing `azure login` and using your work or school username and password when prompted.
trans-unit.target: To see if you have one, log in by typing `azure login` and using your work or school username and password when prompted.

trans-unit.source: If you do have one, you should see something like the following:
trans-unit.target: If you do have one, you should see something like the following:

trans-unit.source: If you do not see this, you must create a new tenant (or service principal) with your Microsoft account identity.
trans-unit.target: If you do not see this, you must create a new tenant (or service principal) with your Microsoft account identity.

trans-unit.source: (This is often the case with personal MSDN subscriptions or free trial subscriptions.) To create a work or school id from your Azure account created with a Microsoft id, see [Associate an Azure AD Directory with a new Azure Subscription](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj573650.aspx#BKMK_WhatIsAnAzureADTenant).
trans-unit.target: (This is often the case with personal MSDN subscriptions or free trial subscriptions.) To create a work or school id from your Azure account created with a Microsoft id, see [Associate an Azure AD Directory with a new Azure Subscription](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj573650.aspx#BKMK_WhatIsAnAzureADTenant).

trans-unit.source: If you think you should have an organizational id already, you may need to talk with the person who created the account for you.
trans-unit.target: If you think you should have an organizational id already, you may need to talk with the person who created the account for you.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Choose your Azure subscription
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Choose your Azure subscription

trans-unit.source: If you have only one subscription in your Azure account, Azure CLI associates itself with that subscription by default.
trans-unit.target: If you have only one subscription in your Azure account, Azure CLI associates itself with that subscription by default.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one subscription, you need to select the subscription you want to use by typing `azure account set <subscription id or name> true` where _subscription id or name_ is either the subscription id or the subscription name that you would like to work with in the current session.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one subscription, you need to select the subscription you want to use by typing `azure account set <subscription id or name> true` where _subscription id or name_ is either the subscription id or the subscription name that you would like to work with in the current session.

trans-unit.target: Step 4: Place your Azure CLI in the ARM mode

trans-unit.source: To use the Azure Resource Management (ARM) mode with the Azure CLI, type `azure config mode arm`.
trans-unit.target: To use the Azure Resource Management (ARM) mode with the Azure CLI, type `azure config mode arm`.
